abstracts.cdata!:
The Bolivia Indigenous Peoples
            Development Project had an unsatisfactory outcome, is
            unlikely to be sustainable, and had a negligible
            institutional development impact. Bank performance was
            satisfactory and Borrower performance was unsatisfactory.
            Several lessons were drawn from this project including the
            following: 1) Culturally-based productive initiatives of
            indigenous producer groups can constitute a financial and
            economic valid alternative for improving their incomes and
            for poverty reduction. 2) Indigenous peoples can improve
            their incomes by accessing markets through the provision of
            products and services that are not necessarily
            "indigenous." 3) It is useful to differentiate
            support for productive initiatives from support for local
            development plans. 4) Project Directorates involving social
            organizations need to reflect the specific composition of
            the intended beneficiaries. 5) Direct transfers induce
            positive effects beyond the objectives of subprojects
            themselves. Effective empowerment is a result of new-found
            confidence in managing projects and funds, and can have
            large spill-over effects over other areas of community life.
            6) Training indigenous people to participate in the
            monitoring and evaluation of poverty reduction policies is
            an important feature for future interventions to have
            adequate impact. 7) A project such as this, which requires
            setting up new institutional mechanisms, and involves actors
            with low capacities, needs to be given sufficient time for
            implementation. Testing out and failure need to be included
            in the design, and sufficient time needs to be allotted for
            follow up and evaluation beyond the investment phase. 8) A
            key lesson learned in this project is the importance of
            proper technical assistance. 9) The failure of the use of a
            management services entity in this particular learning
            process should not invalidate the use of a private
            management unit provided that adequate procedures for the
            selection and supervision processes are followed.
